raw_text:
Final hunts held as ban looms
 
 Hunts in England and Wales have begun on the last day that hunting with dogs is legal, with more due out later.
 
 Thousands of supporters are expected to turn out at more than 250 meets, many of which have altered their normal schedules to be out on a Thursday. The ban on hunting with dogs comes into effect from 0001 GMT on Friday. The Countryside Alliance had its latest legal bid to block the ban thwarted on Wednesday when the Appeal Court ruled the Hunting Act was lawful.
 
 But the group says hunting will continue in some form after the ban comes in, with hunts expected to test the new law to its limits. Others are expected to defy the ban by continuing to hunt illegally.
 
 Anti-hunt organisations, for whom the ban is the culmination of years of campaigning, say they hope most will stay within the law. Mike Hobday, of the League Against Cruel Sports, told BBC News: "We've long urged them to go drag hunting - to follow an artificial scent - and that is what we hope they do. "But if they continue to chase foxes, to chase wild mammals around the countryside, that's against the law and we're confident they'll be brought to justice." At the headquarters of Quorn hunt in Leicestershire, feelings were running high as hunt enthusiasts prepared for their final legal hunt. BBC correspondent Sarah Mukherjee said hunt supporters were in tears.
 
 She said many people did not share the Countryside Alliance's optimism that hunting would be able to continue. Farmer Geoff Brooks, a senior member of the Quorn hunt, told BBC News people's lives "revolved around hunting". He described the ban as "ridiculous" and "badly thought out" but said it would be hard for most people to defy it as they would not want to risk their incomes by getting a criminal record.
 
 At the Court of Appeal on Wednesday, the Countryside Alliance failed in its attempt to have the Hunting Act ruled invalid. But it says the ban is unenforceable because the law is unclear and impossible to police.
 
 The alliance says hunt supporters will go out and test this law to its limits on Saturday. The League Against Cruel Sports and the RSPCA say they will monitor hunts and assist police in bringing prosecutions. The Association of Chief Police Officers has issued guidance to forces on how to deal with the new rules. A spokesman said: "Basically, it's not going to be police officers chasing about in cars across fields, it will be based on intelligence and information received as well." The decision on how to police individual hunts will be left to local forces, with more officers sent to hunts where disruption is expected. He said police would consider evidence submitted by anti-hunt organisations on its merits.
llama3.2:1b:
Final hunts held as ban looms in England and Wales, with thousands of supporters attending over 250 meets.

Hunts are set to begin at 0001 GMT on Friday, but will continue after the law comes into effect, despite the Countryside Alliance's latest bid to block it being thwarted by an appeal court ruling that the Hunting Act is lawful.

Anti-hunt organisations plan to monitor hunts and assist police in bringing prosecutions, while hunt supporters are expected to test the new law.
llama3.2:3b: Hunts in England and Wales began on Thursday on the last day of legal hunting with dogs, as a ban comes into effect from 0001 GMT on Friday. The Countryside Alliance failed to block the ban via court, but claims it is unenforceable due to unclear law. Anti-hunt groups hope most will stay within the law, while others expect to defy the ban by continuing to hunt illegally. Police guidance outlines how they will monitor and assist in prosecutions, with a focus on intelligence rather than chasing hunts.

The Countryside Alliance intends to challenge the ban but hopes to continue hunting in some form. Anti-hunt organizations are confident that most hunts will comply with the law, but they also plan to monitor for illegal activity. Police have been given guidance on how to handle the new regulations, and officers will use intelligence and evidence to address individual hunts.

The banned activity includes chasing foxes or wild mammals around the countryside. Anti-hunt organizations hope most will adhere to the law while some may defy it by continuing illegal activities.
qwen2.5:3b: Final hunting days in England and Wales have commenced ahead of the upcoming ban on hunting with dogs at midnight GMT Friday. Over 250 meets are scheduled, adjusting their usual timeslots due to Thursday hosting. The Countryside Alliance's legal challenge was dismissed by the Appeal Court, making a Hunting Act ban effective from Friday. Despite this, hunts may continue in some form or illegally defy the ban. Anti-hunt groups hope most will comply with law; others expect enforcement through drag hunting rather than traditional fox chasing. Quorn hunt supporters are emotional about their last legal hunt. Farmers like Geoff Brooks see it as a "badly thought out" ban affecting livelihoods, but also predict few would risk breaking the law. The Hunting Act remains unenforceable due to unclear provisions and police guidance emphasizes intelligence-led enforcement.

tinyllama:1.1b:
A summary of the text material presented above is:

- Hunting with dogs in England and Wales has begun, with more than 250 meets scheduled to take place on a Thursday. Hunts are expected to continue in some form after the ban comes into effect from Friday at midnight. Some hunt supporters believe the new law is flawed and will struggle to police it effectively. The League Against Cruel Sports, RSPCA, and Association of Chief Police Officers have issued guidance on how to deal with the new rules. Police forces are expected to take a more nuanced approach than usual, with anti-hunt organisations able to submit evidence to consider.

- Animal lovers hope most will stay within the law, but some hunt supporters believe the ban is unenforceable and will struggle to police it effectively. The allliance has failed to overturn the Hunting Act and faces legal action on Saturday as hunts seek to continue their activities legally under new rules. The guidance suggests policing individual hunts may be left up to local forces, with more officers sent if evidence is found to support an event's disruption.
tinydolphin:1.1b: In England and Wales, hunting with dogs has resumed after the ban comes into effect. However, thousands of supporters gathered at meetings to discuss their views about the new law, which allows only certain types of hunt to continue legally. The Hunting Act was established in 2004, but opponents argue that it fails to protect wildlife and rural environments. Many hunts aim to test the new law by continuing to chase foxes or other animals using artificial scent. Others may go back to their traditional practice of following an animal on foot, which is still a crime in some areas. Meanwhile, anti-hunters hope most will comply with the ban and avoid prosecution.
phi:2.7b: Hunts are taking place in England and Wales before the ban on hunting with dogs comes into effect on Friday, April 1st. The Countryside Alliance has been unsuccessful in their latest legal bid to block the ban, so they predict hunts will continue in some form after the ban is implemented. Supporters of anti-hunting groups hope most hunters will adhere to the new law by following artificial scents instead of chasing wild animals. However, there are concerns that some may still hunt illegally and face consequences such as fines or imprisonment. The Countryside Alliance believes the Hunting Act is unenforceable due to its unclear and impossible-to-police nature.

The ban comes into effect on Friday morning, following a successful Appeal Court ruling against the Countryside Alliance's challenge to the Hunting Act. Despite the legal defeat, the Countryside Alliance expects hunts to continue in some form, testing the new law and potentially operating illegally. Anti-hunt groups, after years of campaigning, hope most will comply with the ban, urging hunters to adopt drag hunting instead. If not, they plan to bring offenders to justice. Law enforcement agencies are preparing to monitor hunts and assist in prosecutions, with local forces deciding how best to police individual events based on intelligence and expected disruptions.
